Cultural hitchhiking and competition between patrilineal kin groups explain the post-Neolithic Y-chromosome bottleneck

In human populations, changes in genetic variation are driven not only by genetic processes, but can also arise from cultural or social changes. An abrupt population bottleneck specific to human males has been inferred across several Old World (Africa, Europe, Asia) populations 5000–7000 BP. Here, bringing together anthropological theory, recent population genomic studies and mathematical models, we propose a sociocultural hypothesis, involving the formation of patrilineal kin groups and intergroup competition among these groups. Our analysis shows that this sociocultural hypothesis can explain the inference of a population bottleneck. We also show that our hypothesis is consistent with current findings from the archaeogenetics of Old World Eurasia, and is important for conceptions of cultural and social evolution in prehistory.

With intergroup competition between patrilineal corporate kin groups, two mechanisms would operate to reduce Y-chromosomal diversity. First, patrilineal corporate kin groups produce high levels of Y-chromosomal homogeneity within each social group due to common descent, as well as high levels of between-group variation. Second, the presence of such groups results in violent intergroup competition preferentially taking place between members of male descent groups, instead of between unrelated individuals. Casualties from intergroup competition then tend to cluster among related males, and group extinction is effectively the extinction of lineages.

There is evidence that other analogous situations involving gene-culture hitchhiking in culturally-defined social groups may have affected genetic diversity. Central Asian pastoralists, who are organized into patriclans, have high levels of intergroup competition and demonstrate ethnolinguistic and population-genetic turnover down into the historical period59. They also have a markedly lower diversity in Y-chromosomal lineages than nearby agriculturalists42,60. In fact, Central Asians are the only population whose male effective population size has not recovered from the post-Neolithic bottleneck; it remains disproportionately reduced, compared to female estimates using mtDNA4. Central Asians are also the only population to have star-shaped expansions of Y-chromosomes within the historical period, which may be due to competitive processes that led to the disproportionate political success of certain patrilineal clans60.

2d is inherently more soulful, and quality hand drawn animation requires actual talent. Translating it to live action immediately removes some of the magic. >>179439523
I'll do it very simply. 2049 proves that Deckard is a replicant, getting rid of all the ambiguity from the prior film, and even shoving in a blatant meta reference to the debate with Deckard not caring if the dog is a replicant or not (revealing how shoddy the writing is to boot).

Deckard is a replicant because the whole point of the movie is finding the chosen child of two replicants, not a human and replicant, since that wouldn't matter so much. But the point of the first film is that Deckard, whether he's human or not, acts completely inhuman in the pursuit of his duty, only being saved by the human act of mercy from Roy at the end before he dies. Indeed, there's a strong argument to be made that the original movie only works if Deckard himself is human and not a replicant, since that heightens the divide between himself and the non-humans he hunts. That's the entire point of the fucking film, asking us what exactly it is to be human, ultimately deciding that it is our acts, our good acts, that gives us our humanity. 2049 then goes on to poke fun at the Deckard-Replicant/Human argument with the dog, without realising that it's own plot requires him to be a replicant. It's dogshit writing from a dogshit director, and I will always be glad that it failed.

I can go on about more if you want, like Jared Leto's godawful performance, or the fact that Deckard isn't even necessary in the film, or that stupid fucking cliche replicant revolution plot that went nowhere, but for the sake of brevity I will leave it there.

I believe the reason we find Jazz so interesting is that he is in many ways quite similar to Sméagol from The Lord of the Rings.
Both are victims of great evil, Sméagol being influenced and corrupted by the One Ring and by extension Sauron, while Jazz is manipulated by his mother and by extension Satan. However they are also victims of their own making, choosing to embrace the very evil that has corrupted them, and that is what makes them so frustratingly interesting. In some way deep down they both know how marred they are, however, they refuse to change and would rather die in their misery than suffer the pain of conquering themselves.
Truly horrifying once you realise such a fate could have befallen one of us.

>>179430648
>promethazine
But yeah, in Prometheus they wear suits and helmet (at least, for a big part of the move), in Covenant, they don't, and it's stupid to blame them for that, or even worst, to think that this was used to make the plot happen with the black goo spores lol.

The reasoning why it make sense for them to take out their helmet in a new planet, it's because they have a the technology to know if yes or not, the air is irreparable, and they obliviously trust that technology, like you trust your thermometer.

Now, yes, they should have been more careful and run around with different systems and devices to constantly scan their environment about possible virus and other parasites (not only in the air, but also on grass, water, tress and what not), here, yes, it's rather dumb for them to act that naively. But then again, how much experience do they have in that situation ? Have they have been trained to land on different new planets ? No. Do they have a proper chain of commands with a list of check to past before doing any moves ? No, since their original commander is dead, and the new one is literally fighting to get his orders passed. Point is, again, this turn of events look logical, everything is snow balling since the death of the main commander, and all the decisions and leadership is literally pure non sense, which when you look at it, it's not different than in real life (cf, most of you have seen enough video on liveleak and /b/ to know that a lot of humans are dumb as a rock).

So all in all, while I can accept that the movie fail to create the perfect illusion of "realism" and "immersion" with those dumb characters, I still think that in the end, they are not that unrealistic or totally out of the normal attitude that most humans would react.

The Mega-Federation launched the ÜberEnterprise on the 10,000th anniversary of James T. Kirk's five-year mission, which had commenced in 2265. The ship was crewed by holographic replica of the USS Enterprise and USS Enterprise-D senior staff, and held a total complement of one million Photonics. Unifleet charged them with a hundred-year mission to explore the local galactic supercluster.

The ship returned to Mega-Federation space from its extra-galactic excursion in 12,365, Unifleet agreed with co-captains Picard and Kirk to allow the Enterprise on an unlimited mission.

Over the course of hundreds of thousands of years, the Enterprise visited numerous galaxies. Kirk found that Deanna Troi and Spock worked well together when their psionic gifts were needed.

While the ÜberEnterprise continued its mission of exploration and set up proto-Federations ready to merge with the Mega-Federation eventually, the population of the Mega-Federation began to evolve into incorporeality. In 762,260, Unifleet stopped transmitting to the Enterprise when the Milky Way Galaxy population merged into the non-corporeal Convergence. The Mega-Federation ceased to exist. To maintain the mission, the Soong-breed android Data Soong faked continued orders from Unifleet, keeping the crew in the dark about losing their nation.

By 1,007,260, Soong had realized that he was stuck as the only corporeal being among a crew of holograms, and that he would be stuck like that for eternity. Soong locked himself into his quarters, began genetic engineering of his cats and focused on artistic pursuits. His friend Geordi La Forge was unable to determine the sudden character change.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179432988
Rewatched them recently.

TFA is serviceable, it's an enjoyable enough SW movie. My issue with it is that they decided to double down on fan service instead of making it stand by itself but I understand that as a business decision.

TLJ is GREATLY improved by via fanedits. I watched one called The Fallen Knight that removed a good chunk of the jokes, Finn and Rose's arc and Holdo, focusing it on Rey, Luke and Kylo. Plinkett was right that it should have ended on a cliffhanger with Rey debating taking Kylo's hand

ROS is disappointing - it had a lot of elements I really liked but it suffered from
>get the maguffin to go to the place to get the next maguffin
It should have been a lot more focused. Also they seem to have cut out some of the elements like Vader's castle which would have made it more interesting in favour of Alpaca Planet.

Overall the idea of a trilogy based around a sith guy and jedi girl bound together mysteriously through the force was great, but they botched the execution by not planning it right. TFA was fine but really TLJ was the problem, then ROS didn't manage to salvage it.

The idea of Rey being a Palpatine isn't terrible imo - the issue was that the Emperor was in the movie at all. ROS should have begun with the assumption that Rey *did* take Kylo's hand, with a small timeskip. Kylo should have returned to being Ben (although I thought this was done nicely in ROS, it's a tender moment when Rey heals him) but Rey's sith nature comes out and she goes bad. Then ironically Rey is the villain and Kylo needs to stop her. At the end, Kylo, Finn and Friends manage to exorcise the Sith from her and she returns to normal, Kylo sacrificing himself to do so. The end.

>>179414965
It was probably a suicide. That's why Vernon Presley ensured the details of the autopsy would remain hidden. Here are the memories of Elvis' stepbrother:

>The minute I walked in there, I knew. "You son of a bitch," I yelled. Elvis was lying there, with pills and empty syringes all around, and I had no doubt what had happened. None. And it just pissed me off. It hurt, but it made me mad, too. Damn it, Elvis! But I didn't spend a lot of time hurting right away, because it was so instilled in me to take care of business. And that's what I did, picking up syringes, picking up the pills. And I've gotten a lot of heat for that. Geraldo Rivera said that's obstruction of justice. But I didn't care. All I knew was there was an ambulance crew fixing to walk through that door and there's stuff lying all over the place, and I had to clean this place up now. So I grabbed everything I could and stuffed it in my pocket and then moved over to Elvis. He was lying face down, kind of all curled up. We turned him over and his eyes were rolled back in his head. His face was blue, bloated, and his tongue was sticking out of his mouth, black, and half bitten off. He was gone.

>Joe Esposito, Al Strada, Billy Smith, Charlie Hodge and I were standing in a waiting room while all the efforts were being made to revive Elvis. A doctor came in and Joe asked, "How long has Elvis been without oxygen?" The doctor's response was too long in coming. Joe said, "I guess we should hope he's gone, otherwise he would just be a living vegetable." Moments later Dr. Nick walked in the room and just lowered his head. We already knew, but Elvis was officially pronounced dead. At that moment time stood still. My mind flashed back to that November 22nd day when President John F. Kennedy died. Family and friends much like us were the first to hear the news that would forever be inscribed in the minds of the whole world.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DMmpN6eETP8

It's on youtube and it's a good story, but if you don't want to watch it

>Kevin Smith is contacted by Warner Brothers
>ends up writing a script for a Superman movie
>gets to the point of meeting with the producer
>producer wants him to rewrite it to fit in things he thinks would be cool and make for good action scenes
>producer is demanding he write in all kinds of dumb animal-related shit like a polar bear fight or find a way to include a giant spider
>"you know anything about spiders?"
>Kevin: "no..."
>"well they're the fiercest killers in the insect kingdom"
>"okay, I'll try to fit a big alien spider thing into it somehow..."
>everything's going okay until Tim Burton is hired on as director
>Tim Burton wants his own writers to do the script so the studio drops Kevin's script
>Kevin shrugs and forgets about it until the producer contacts him again to invite him to see the premier of his new movie
>name of the movie is Wild Wild West
>halfway through the movie a giant spider shows up
